turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Justice Powell.
We'll hear arguments first this morning in United States against Valenzuela-Bernal.
Mr. Phillips, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This case is here on a writ of certiorari at the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, three questions presented.

First, the United States violates a criminal defendant's Fifth Amendment due process or Sixth Amendment compulsory process rights when it deports an illegal alien after making a reasonable investigation in concluding that the illegal alien has no material exculpatory evidence to make available to the defendant.

Second, assuming that the Government acts at its peril in deporting illegal aliens while the defendant in order to state a constitutional violation still must demonstrate that the laws of the illegal alien has caused him a concrete loss of material exculpatory evidence.

Finally, assuming that the Court of Appeals is correct, that the -- that the respondent's constitutional rights are violated when the defendant is deprived of no more than the loss of a conceivable benefit or the proper remedy for that technical constitutional violation is dismissal of the indictment against the respondent.
On March 29th, 1980, respondent was captured in the process of transporting five illegal aliens from Escondido, California to Los Angeles.
The circumstances surrounding respondent's arrest were explained by respondent in his own post arrest statement volunteered to Border Patrol agents.
Respondent is an illegal alien from Mexico, he entered the -- he entered this country approximately six days prior to his arrest with the assistance of an illegal alien smuggler.
He had been kept in a house in Escondido prior up to the day of his arrest.
On the day he was arrested, he agreed with the illegal alien smuggler to transport five additional illegal aliens to Los Angeles in return for the price of his illegal entry into this country.

Respondent had been told that the Border Patrol agents at the Temecula checkpoint were not actually checking for illegal aliens; unfortunately, for respondent, he was misinformed and was pulled over to the side or at least was motioned over to the side.
He slowed the car down and then drove away at a very high rate of speed.
Border Patrol agents chased him, two agents in a single car and respondent stopped his car approximately a mile away from the checkpoint and fled on foot along with the other five illegal aliens.
Respondent and three illegal aliens were captured by the Border Patrol agents; two other illegal aliens, however, escaped.
The Border Patrol agents then returned the respondent back to the Border Patrol checkpoint, informed the respondent of his right to remain silent.
He, however, waives the right and agreed to make a statement under oath.
In the recorded statement, he explained his decision to flee from the Border Patrol checkpoint on the basis, “I already knew that I had had it, too late.
It was done.”
Later, he told the agents, “I acknowledge the charge of driving.”
The agents also interviewed the other illegal aliens and they all admitted that they were in the county illegally and the respondent had been the driver of the car.
The Border Patrol agent at that point or soon thereafter called the Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of California for advice as to how to proceed in the case.

The Assistant U.S. Attorney based on the information regarding the respondent's apparent confession, the accumulative nature of -- of the statements made by the three additional illegal aliens and the general circumstances surrounding the arrest, the flight, et cetera, decided that no useful purpose would be served either for the Government or for the defendant in requiring two otherwise none -- not prosecutable by our -- in our discretion, however, but not prosecutable illegal aliens to remain in custody and therefore authorized the release of those two illegal aliens back in Mexico.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Were any statements taken from them before they were released?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, sir.
There were.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What happened to the statement?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, unfortunately, the tape recorder had malfunctioned.

Originally, it was thought that the tape recording of respondent's statement had malfunctioned and there was no statement from him but it turned out that the malfunction was -- occurred during the time that the statements of the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So in fact there is no written or recorded statement from those released?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, not a specific written or recorded statement; although I think typically there would be, moreover, we do of course have the statement from the remaining illegal alien, Romero-Morales, and the statements from the Border Patrol agents, and all the statements by all of the agents -- or excuse me, by all of the illegal aliens are essentially the same.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And when did you get -- when did they get the statement from Morales?
Sometime --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Subsequently when he testified at the -- at the hearing, they received -- they obtained that statement and there's nothing to indicate that his statement at the hearing on the motion to dismiss was different from the statement given to the Border Patrol agents at the time of his arrest.
The Assistant United States Attorney authorized the release of two of the three illegal aliens chosen at random and they were released on March 30th of --

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Phillips --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, ma'am.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: -- I assume the Government could have prosecuted the witnesses who were deported --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, ma'am.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: -- for a criminal offense.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, ma'am.We could have prosecuted them for illegal entry into this country.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But it is the general practice not to do that and to simply deport them.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It is significantly easier, Your Honor, our resources to do that.
Yes, ma'am.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There's no claim, I take it here, that the respondent himself transported the illegal aliens across the border --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- just they transported them after they were in the country, and they hadn't been here for a year.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's correct.
That's correct, Your Honor.

The two illegal aliens were returned on March 30 concededly prior to the time the respondent's counsel had any opportunity to interview them.The respondent was indicted on one count of transporting --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Was the respondent represented and did the prosecutor know that at the time they were released?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, the respondent was not represented by a counsel.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: He was not represented?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Ultimately, did -- was he represented by a retained or appointed counsel?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I believe it was appointed counsel.
Respondent was indicted on one count of transporting an illegal alien, Romero-Morales, within this country in violation of 8 U.S.C. 1324(a)(2).
Soon thereafter, he filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that the deportation of the two illegal aliens had the prior -- had violated his Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights.
District Court held a hearing on the motion at that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did he make any proffer of what the testimony would be given had these people been kept in the country?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Not specifically, the closest thing to a proffer, I suppose, would be -- he did offer a testimony of Romero-Morales at the hearing.

Romero-Morales was at least putatively a defense witness at the hearing on the motion to dismiss; although I submit that his statements were rather strongly inculpatory of respondent rather than exculpatory.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, before you -- before you go on, can I get the time sequence a little in my mind?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The man was arrested on the 29th of March, was it?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the other occupants of the vehicle were sent back on the 30th.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And he was arraigned on the 31st, was it, the next day?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.
I think so.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, when -- was a counsel appointed for him on the 31st?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I assume that that was the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So it would have been a question of whether to hold him for one day to give the counsel an opportunity to interview him.
Is that what we're pointing to?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: In this specific case it would have been but there was no way, I don't think, of knowing that at the time necessarily.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, isn't there a procedure whereby these things are processed in this manner normally and wouldn't you normally expect the complaint to be filled rather promptly?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, we would assume that; although, of course, it's -- it's not really accurate -- altogether accurate to say that it's only holding him for a single day.

I mean other than the fact that he would have had counsel appointed at that point, there still presumably would have been a period of time the counsel would have required in order to investigate the matter and to pursue it.
Typically, the practice is to keep the illegal aliens for 10 days even after a counsel is appointed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The -- the practice is to keep them for 10 days?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: After -- I see, is that the -- well, I don't understand.
I'm a little puzzled.
What is the source of the 10-day practice?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It's just a -- it's a common law practice.
I think it's developed primarily by the magistrates in the Southern District of California; although it is also adopted in other districts.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then why wasn't it followed in this case?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, because the case wasn't submitted to -- it wasn't -- the illegal aliens were already gone prior to the time that it went to the magistrate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In order to avoid the 10-day rule, you must ship them back before the magistrate complaint is filed, is that right?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, in a sense, yes, Your Honor because the problem is that given the state of the law in the Ninth Circuit, the magistrate's simply not in a position to release the illegal aliens unless we -- unless we can modify the Ninth Circuit's very strict ruling, it's very difficult to have a magistrate agree to release the illegal aliens even though there is no likelihood of --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Would the Government's problem be solved if the Ninth Circuit rule were modified to require them to be kept safe for 24 hours or --?
It seems to me that there is -- the dispute may be narrower than it appears to be.

You know, that the other side seems to be just asking for an opportunity to interview and the ten -- I can see your objection to the 10-day rule but I wonder if it necessarily would apply to say, a 24-hour rule.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I suspect that -- I mean, obviously, the Government's position would be immaterially advanced by a 24-hour rule but I'm not sure that the decision as to how much time is one -- that is a -- you know, it's not an easy judgment to make and certainly, I wouldn't -- it's a --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: -- close legislative judgment.
I don't --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Apart from that, Mr. Phillips, I gather or perhaps I better put it as a question, do you think the -- they could have been released had counsel in fact been appointed before they were released?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, it might have been -- it would have been significantly more difficult.
I mean it would certainly --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well -- no, I --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Without consulting a counsel, you mean?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Yes.
Would the Government's case be in any trouble if you did that?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, I don't think so because it's still -- our submission is that there was no prejudice whatsoever and the -- and -- and even if there were some claim that we violated his right to counsel, you would still have to have a demonstration of prejudice.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You mean there's no Messiah overtone after a counsel is appointed to whether or not you could -- may release them?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, you don't have there -- I mean I -- no, I don't think -- no, sir.
No, Your Honor.

At the test -- at the hearing on the motion to dismiss, testimony was offered by the two arresting Border Patrol agents, the detained illegal alien, Romero-Morales, and the Assistant United States Attorney who approved the release of the two illegal aliens.

Based largely on the post arrest admissions by the respondent, the District Court held that the loss of the missing illegal aliens could not possibly or at least with no substantial possibility have prejudiced defendant's -- respondent's case and therefore, he denied the motion to dismiss.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When did the respondent know that the witnesses were being set away?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: When did he learn that the witnesses had been sent away?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Uh-hmm.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I suspect probably on the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You suspect?
You don't know?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I don't know exactly when they -- when he was informed.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But if he'd had a lawyer you would know, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I assume his attorney was probably informed on the 31st.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: His attorney on the 31st, so neither the respondent nor his lawyer to be appointed had any opportunity to oppose the removal of the witnesses?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's absolutely correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What was happening to this third witness in the meantime?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: He is being detained -- he was -- he was detained in custody as a material witness for the Government or -- and also for the defendant as it turns out -- I mean, for the respondent as it turns out he -- he did testify on behalf of the respondent.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did he testify?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Yes, Your Honor, he did.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But he was called by --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: He was called by the respondent.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- the defendant.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: And his statement was that he wasn't an illegal alien, that he had been in this country for less than two days at the time that the respondent transported him, that the respondent was the -- was the driver of the car.
So then -- while he was nominally a witness on behalf of the respondent, in reality I submit that his testimony was rather inculpatory.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let me go back to my former question about whether there was a proffer.

Was there any suggestion whether a proffered testimony or otherwise that the two who were going back to Mexico, then deported, would have justified to any factors which were not available from the witness who was detained?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, Your Honor, none whatsoever.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, how would -- how would anybody have made that proffer if -- could never have a -- if there was no opportunity to chat with those witnesses?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the circumstance -- I mean, the respondent had ample opportunity to chat with those witnesses, Your Honor.
He was at the house at the time prior to the transportation, he was in the car the whole time during the transportation, and he was there at the time of the arrest.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, he was -- I think he was but his lawyer never had a chance to -- to talk with him, did he?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, but his lawyer certainly had access to the respondent and to any information that the respondent has.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That may be so but the respondent probably didn't know what he was -- that A, he's going to charged or B, what he's going to be charged with --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, even if --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- or what the elements of the crime were.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, even if respondent couldn't make an immediate judgment as to how to proceed in this matter, certainly sometime between the period or the time when he was arrested and the post arrest period all the way up until the time of the trial respondent had ample opportunity to explain to his attorney what possible defenses might be available and even to this day we still have nothing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's hardly -- that's hardly equivalent to -- that's hardly equivalent to knowing what the witnesses would have said in response to questions from the lawyer.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, concededly it is somewhat different; although it is not -- I mean, this Court has never had any trouble in the Roviaro context in --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Don't you -- your first submission as I understand it is that the Government should be relied on to decide whether a witness has anything relevant that might help the defendant.
That's a very strange submission, isn't it?
I thought defendants usually decide what -- what's the point --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, it's not that we're really -- I mean actually not, I mean if we were to take -- if we were to reason by analogy from United States versus Lovasco, it would seem to us that the rule ought to be that the United States simply in pursuing its policy with regard to immigration, should simply deport the illegal aliens.

All we do in this context is attempt to provide a certain amount of protection for the respondent by virtue of the fact that we provide him with certain amount of protection.I don't think that should give raise to any inherent problems.
I mean, otherwise, we would just simply deport him as the Court held in United States versus Rose on the First Circuit decision.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, would you say that -- would you say that if you interviewed them and you thought there was something helpful to the defendant that you can nevertheless deport them?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, our assumption would be no.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: There was reason to suspect --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why?
You've got a power to deport.
Just deport.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's true.
Concededly we have the power to do that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Just deport them without talking to them.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, that's exactly what the Court's sanctioned in United States versus Rose but we're not asking this Court to adapt that view although as I said it would certainly -- it would certainly further our immigration policies if the Court order were to adapt that view, but we're prepared to give the respondent perhaps more protection than he otherwise might require.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You already talked to them because you want to get a witness for yourself.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You -- you interviewed the -- you interviewed the people because you need witnesses yourself.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Admittedly we do but we also in the process of interviewing a witness on our -- in order to determine whether there is any inculpatory evidence we necessarily discover whether there's any exculpatory evidence.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Counsel, what is the Government's main concern, saving the -- the cost involved in maintaining these witnesses in jail over a long period of time or what?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I mean, certainly the cost is a significant factor but I think the idea of -- of having illegal aliens languishing in jail for a period of time when no one has any intention of calling them as witnesses either the Government or the defendant and no one has -- you know, and they're not going to serve any useful function to anybody, I think that's the primary interest to the Federal Government in these cases.

And to go back to the statistics that we cited in our brief, it -- there's something wrong with the rule of law that requires the Federal Government to detain 5,000 illegal aliens as material witnesses in a district in which there are 36 trials on Title 8 offenses.
There's something just fundamentally wrong with that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What about the various alternatives suggested by the respondents that might alleviate the problem?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, our submission is that none of those -- that none of those alternatives is very useful.
Specifically, they suggest the use of work farms.
The United States -- the Southern District of California at least does not have a work farm.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, how about an early interview at which defense counsel has an opportunity to be present --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: -- before release?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The difficulty with that, with the idea of an early interview is one, it's difficult just to get -- get counsel appointed.
I mean a lot of this -- a lot of captures are not in locations where counsel is close by so there's certainly a period of time lost in that process.
Second of all, it's not altogether clear what an early interview will accomplish.

Testimony by the Assistant United States Attorney at the -- at the hearing on the motion to dismiss was to the effect that oftentimes defense counsel prefers to be able to try to retain illegal alien material witnesses even without any expectation of having them testify simply as leverage against the Government for a plea bargain arrangement so that I'm not sure that we're going to be at anything by virtue of having -- having counsel there earlier.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What the --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you mean as leverage for a plea bargain?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the -- I mean if -- it is absolutely true that the Government can only hold so many material witnesses.
As it stands now we are running out of space in the state jails.
And when we get to the point when we can hold no more illegal aliens we simply either have to release the defendants or release the illegal aliens and thereby end up losing our ability to prosecute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Under the rule of the Ninth Circuit?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Under the rule of the Ninth Circuit, Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, on the proffer point that was raised by the Chief Justice, what is this stipulation on page 22 of the joint appendix?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That was a stipulation offered by the Assistant United States Attorney, Your Honor, that we were willing to -- we were willing to stipulate that the illegal aliens --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But this wasn't agreed to?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
At least if it was there was nothing in the record to suggest that anybody responded to it.
But it was our stipulation that we were willing to say that none of the illegal aliens had told --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But it says, “It is hereby ordered that the substance of paragraphs belongs to--”

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Oh, I'm sorry.
As I said, the stipulation with regard to the oral -- with regard to the trial on the basis of the record that was produced at the oral hearing.
I'm sorry, Your Honor, at the hearing to the -- on the motion to dismiss, that stipulation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But that -- it --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That was agreed to, yes, that's why there wasn't a trial in this case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, does this excuse the proffer or not?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
All that does is explain why there wasn't a specific trial in the case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's my point.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What were you referring to?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I was just -- referring to the offer to stipulate on the part of the Government that the illegal aliens who had been deported would not testify -- would not have testified that they had told the respondent that they were illegal aliens and have been in this country for more than three years.
Basically, we're willing to agree that to the Romero-Morales' testimony which was that they never said anything at all in that automobile.
And so in order to prove respondent's knowledge we were going to have to use the circumstances.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: There was no response and no counter offer.
Will you please stipulate that if they recall they would testify as follows?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, nothing at all was said at all on that point, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's awfully difficult for me to imagine how a lawyer who never talked to the people could proffer anything.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, he has -- he still has access to the respondent.
I'm not -- you know -- this is not a case of mistaken identity.
This individual was there at all relevant times.
As the Fifth Circuit said, “You can typically tell in these cases what exactly happened.”
And so the respondent was in the presence of the missing witnesses at all times.
He presumably can suggest something.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm not talking about the respondent; I'm talking about the lawyer.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the lawyer has access to the respondent.
I mean, there's no reason to assume the respondent would lie to him.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He might not know what the important point is.
That's why he has a lawyer.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Certainly, Your Honor, and that's why his attorney can --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I get back to the point, why couldn't he have -- around for one day?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, because one day wouldn't have gained us anything, Your Honor.
One day would not have gained us anything in most instances.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It would have allowed the lawyer to talk to him.
It wouldn't have gained you anything.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No.
And it wouldn't have gained anybody anything in the facts of this case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It would allow the lawyer to talk to the witnesses.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: So, I mean, -- well, it wouldn't have allowed the lawyer to make any kind of a reasonable conversation with the witnesses because they had no opportunity to investigate the matter.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The great thing was could -- it would -- I didn't have to ask the question.
It's obvious that in one day, the lawyer could have talked to the witnesses.
You can either admit it or let it go.
It's alright with me.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, he could have talked to them but I'm not sure that anything meaningful would have come from that conversation, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you never are but couldn't he have asked him a few questions?
Like when did you come into the country and what was your arrangement?
And take a 10-minute interview, facts that maybe his client would not have known because I think you indicated the driver of the vehicle didn't necessarily talk to all the passengers.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No.
There's no question --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is it possible the lawyer could have found out something by direct conversation that he could not have found out through his client?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: You mean as to their illegal alien status?
I mean, the only person whose illegal alien status is relevant to this prosecution, however, is Romero-Morales.
And Romero-Morales is available to talk with the attorney.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Could the Government have deported him?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: You mean aside from the Fifth and Sixth Amendment problems?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, no, under your view of this case, would it have been permissible for the Government to deport him as well as all the other passengers?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, it would have been -- the problem that that would have created is we would have a no -- we would have lacked a non-hearsay basis for proving some of the elements and perhaps created a Confrontation Clause problem.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Assume you had a statement that you thought was sufficient from the driver himself plus the testimony of the two agents who arrested the -- arrested them, that might have made out a sufficient case, just assume.
I think that's possible.
Then I suppose under your view, you could also have deported the man who was the -- actually, the charge was based on, under your view of the law.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I suspect that we might well have been able to do that although --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the question we have to decide, would that have been consistent with the Constitution?
That's really the issue.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Sure, but there was still -- and you have to analyze it in two different grounds.

One, on the basis of the reasonableness of our decision to release him, which is probably questionable on those circumstances since there's no -- since the detention of one illegal alien versus three is -- is perhaps not all that onerous a burden on us.
Second of all, you still would have to show that he was a material witness in any sense.

I mean typically, this is -- in some ways, it's unfortunate to this case -- in this case that the -- that the tape recorder broke because, typically, we would have an oral statement on -- from everyone that we could then examine.
And that would presumably serve as at least some basis for the counsel to inquire as to what possible grounds --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it wouldn't hurt you much then if you lost this case.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It wouldn't hurt you much then if you lost this case in the sense that the next case where the tape recorded statement would be different.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, if you were prepared -- if the Court were to hold that it is abundantly clear that if we had that statement in hand, we can go ahead and deport the illegal aliens.
That may well be true.
But what we're looking for -- I mean this specific -- this specific case is not what's terribly important.
This is not a case about two illegal aliens and one criminal defendant.
This is a case literally about thousands of illegal aliens.
The United States captures -- has captured in each of the last three years one million illegal aliens.
Each of those, not every one of those illegal aliens, of course necessarily raises the Mendez-Rodriguez problem.

Now if you consider that most of them probably had some assistance coming into this country, probably had some assistance in trying to conceal themselves from the authorities and probably, because of where they ended up having to stay within this country came across criminal activity of another nature, the chances of a Mendez-Rodriguez problem with regard to all one million of those illegal aliens is fairly good.
And it cannot be that the Government is responsible to keep all of those illegal aliens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, suppose it were perfectly clear that a counsel would always be appointed in the vast majority of instances within 24 hours after arrest or 48 hours after arrest.
And the rule was that you should -- that you should give counsel one day and then you can deport witnesses.
Now, you would have to hold all these people for three days.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, that's not altogether clear, your Honor.
I mean, the question is, does that mean after they interview them and regardless of what they say, we then have the right to go ahead and deport them?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Or what if they interpose an objection is the problem.
They then interpose an objection, we go to a magistrate, the magistrate under the Ninth Circuit's regiment --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You would be in no different position than you would be if -- if somehow this alien, this defendant had a -- had a lawyer within the room when he was arrested and he went around and he subpoenaed all these witnesses.
What would you do with him then, deport him?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, if he asked -- if he -- well, no, obviously, if he had a subpoena in hand, we might try to fight the subpoena.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's just one of those -- one of those problems about what the Government does.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, does a subpoena protect you from deporting him?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I think if -- I guess a subpoena doesn't actually act against the Government.
It acts -- it acts against the illegal alien.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You might -- consequences might attach to your deportation of him, but I wouldn't think that --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, that's true.
It wouldn't directly prohibit us from -- from deporting -- that's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you wouldn't deport him, I don't suppose.
Would you?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I suspect we would not.
No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't understand why under a 24-hour rule, you would be precluded from deporting them after they've been interviewed because the burden would remain on the defendant to make a showing that their testimony would have been material, I would suppose.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor, I missed that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You seem to assume that if there were a 24-hour rule where you would just -- somehow there'd be a counsel appointed immediately then they interview, you seem to be assuming you could not then immediately deport if you're satisfied they have nothing material to present because then I would suppose if you did deport, the lawyer having interviewed the -- the person would be in a position to make a showing if he could that there was some material --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, but I guess -- I guess our response to that is I don't see that there's any significant difference between what we've done here because I don't think that the -- the appointment of a counsel in this situation would have materially altered the ultimate findings of the District Court that should have been upheld by the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's if you assume that the prosecutor should be the one who does the investigating for defense counsel on the facts.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, it's only -- but it's only that the -- that the Government makes the initial determination.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I know but it's a determination that --

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: And then subsequently, that's subject to review.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- totally forecloses the opportunity for the defense counsel to -- to investigate.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But that -- I mean I guess our response to that is that there -- it's just not simply realistic to say that they cannot know.
I mean, I don't see how this case is distinguishable from Roviaro, where you're denied access to the confidential informant unless you can make a showing that he has some materiality.
You don't -- you've never talked to him.
The assumption is because you were present at the crime that you can take action.
And therefore -- and this Court has consistently upheld the right of the Government to deny you access to the confidential informant in those circumstances.
We submit that the Government's interest in this case is every bit as great as in that case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean that on the day of the hearing, they couldn't have talked to these witnesses if they were there?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, of course they could have talked to them if they had been there, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's what you meant then.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I will reserve the rest of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Iredale?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I'd like to address four of the issues in this case.
First is the issue of what the statute with which Mr. Valenzuela was charged required for proof of conviction and what the defense in the case was.
Secondly, the way in which the Government's action in this case violated the Sixth Amendment right to compulsory process.

Third, what the actual procedure is in the Southern District of California in implementing the Ninth Circuit decision in Mendez-Rodriguez, a decision that has been adapted by the Circuits -- of the three other Circuits, the Fifth, the Seventh, and recently in Armijo-Martinez, the Sixth.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, the -- the Fifth is a little different, isn't it?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun, as we talk about that in the brief, the original decision was Avila-Dominguez.
And in that case, the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held that deportation of the witnesses before an interview is a violation of due process, the sanction for which is dismissal.
However, they said we reject the automatic dismissal rule.
The Ninth Circuit of course does not have an automatic dismissal rule.

And in a subsequent case (Inaudible), the Fifth Circuit said that the standard is that the defense in order to obtain relief must show either a plausible theory or some slight suggestion concerning which the witnesses could have helped.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: That strikes me as out of line with the Ninth Circuit's approach.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, whether you call it --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I'm just objecting to your saying that this Circuit has followed the Ninth.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I -- I should say that with the exception -- to our mind, the difference between the terms plausible theory or some slight suggestion and the Ninth Circuit formulation of conceivable benefit is a matter of semantics.
But I think you're correct that there is some difference in the formulation of the test although the Fifth has held that deportation in this context violates compulsory process.
Finally, I'd like to discuss the Government's proposal and why it would strike at the heart of the adversary process, which is the basis for our criminal justice system.
The respondent was charged in this case with a violation of --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Iredale, before you go on to that section, am I correct in thinking that the Ninth Circuit did not require the defendant to make any sort of a showing here before it dismissed the indictment?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
The Ninth Circuit requires that the defendant show some conceivable benefit could have been gained from the testimony of these witnesses.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What did the defendant show here?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: In the District Court, the defendant submitted an exhibit.
We actually tried to subpoena these witnesses.

We obtained the addresses in Mexico, mailed them subpoenas although of course, the subpoenas have no force outside the geographical limits of the United States except with respect to United States citizens.

We also mailed a parole letter, which was countersigned by the U.S. Attorney authorizing the witness, should the witness choose to attend Court entering to the United States; the parole is the permit to let him in.
And finally, we sent a letter to each of the witnesses in these cases which was submitted as an exhibit at the hearing on a motion to dismiss.

In each of the letters, the counsel in the case wrote to the witness, “Your testimony regarding any conversations that occurred between Mr. Valenzuela, yourself and other occupants of the vehicle is important in the case of Mr. Valenzuela.

Further, your physical appearance on the date of the arrest and any information you provided or did not provide to Mr. Valenzuela concerning your illegal status and time and place of illegal entry in the United States is important to the issues of guilt or innocence.”

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could you have taken their testimony by deposition?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Had they been held?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No.
In Mexico.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: In Mexico?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What -- what could prevent you from taking that except the dollars?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Dollars and the logistical difficulty, otherwise, I believe --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And in terms of distance from where you were operating, how far were these witnesses away?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I may be wrong but I think that Jalisco was about 800 to 1000 miles away and the other witness was in another province.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And they put them pretty far down in Southern Mexico.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
In other words, unless the deposition could be taken before the police have witnesses --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that in the record?
Is their location in the record?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: It is because the exhibit was introduced as an exhibit.
It's in the record before the Court of Appeals albeit not in the joint appendix before this Court.
But their address, La Huerta, Jalisco for one of the witnesses and the other address in another State in Mexico is in the record.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I understand your statement as to what the defendants showed here were simply letters to the missing witnesses saying that it would be very desirable to interview them on certain points.
Was there nothing more than that?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, Your Honor, there was also a statement in argument by counsel that we wanted the witnesses because we felt that they could possibly testify in such a way as he might be found not guilty of a crime of knowingly transporting aliens.

And then this followed a colloquy when the Assistant U.S. Attorney was on the stand in which the questions were asked which set forth the defense in this case, the defense which the Ninth Circuit recognized in this opinion.
One of the elements of illegal transportation of aliens is that a person has to have reasonable grounds knowing that the people came into the United States within the last three years.
The prosecutor answered that's correct.
The Ninth Circuit recognized that that was the basis or conceivable benefit.
In other words, we showed both in the District Court and to the Ninth Circuit that these witnesses could have proffered evidence that would have been relevant to the defense.
What was that defense?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Relevant, one where it would have helped the Government.
It would have helped you.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, and because we didn't have the witnesses, we'll never be able to know for sure.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, couldn't the defendant himself have made some sort of an affidavit or proffer if in fact he hadn't talked to any of the deported witnesses in the car?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, there are several reasons why that would not be, I would suggest, an appropriate procedure.
First of all is the fact that the -- as a general matter, the defendant may not have himself knowledge of the relevant evidence that can be given by the witnesses.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but after that, I mean you're now at the hearing stages, talked to his lawyer and presumably has a much better idea from his lawyer than he would have had on his own.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He has the Fifth Amendment right not to testify.
There's no --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Sure, he has other kinds of rights that if he doesn't testify, he may not help himself.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I understand that, Your Honor.

But the point is I think that in the absence of some immunity in the Simmons context that the defendant could get up on the stand or submit an affidavit which could later be used -- parts of which could later be used at the trial and the case in chief to convict him, and that would be an inappropriate showing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, presumably if he swears to something and says, “I didn't talk to these witnesses while they're in the car.”
The only need -- the only theory you need to have is that the witnesses will actually come back and say, “Yes, he did talk to me a lot in the car.”
And I don't see that that's unduly penalized, I mean, if he swears to something under oath.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the Ninth Circuit and none of the other Circuits have ever made a requirement that the defendant himself make a showing.
The issue is --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, we're reviewing the Ninth Circuit here.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, I understand.

I think the appropriate test would be not to require the defendant to come forth and make any showing but to allow his counsel by statement or by some indication as to the possible defense to show how these witnesses could have helped were they here, and that's what was done in this case.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mister --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: All counsel could do is tell what the elements of the offense are.
He can't say what the -- the defendant will know much more about counsel as to the factual basis.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He may or may not depending on the facts of the case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Iredale, could the defendant not testify for purposes of the hearing only and preserve his right not to testify at trial and not have it used against him as much as we would have happen at other pretrial hearings?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.
That's my point, Justice O'Connor.
It's not clear whether there would be a Simmons protection, in other words, whether that could not be used by the prosecutor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That has not been tested to your knowledge.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: It has never been raised.
And so, because there was no such requirement in this case, counsel would have in effect been risking, allowing his client to get on the stand.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But certainly, that would be one possibility, would it not?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: As to the showing, as to the showing --

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: For the showing of possible prejudice, wouldn't that be a possibility?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I think it could be except that it would trench on the defendant's Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.

I think the rule, which we have, is an appropriate one which is counsel must show given the facts and the law and the statute involved that these witnesses could conceivably because we'll never know for sure what they would have had.
They could have given evidence that would have helped this case.
Now, let -- let me just address this because the Government seems to say, “This defendant was so guilty, it doesn't matter.”

Well, certainly, there was no question that he transported the persons, that one of them in fact was an alien and given all of the evidence in the light most favorable to the Government, possibly even that he knew of his illegal status.
But 8 U.S.C. 1324(a)(2), the statute employed in this case, requires that the defendant know that the alien had entered illegally within the last three years before the transportation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What was the testimony of the one who went -- and so did remain?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: The testimony in that regard, Your Honor, was that he did not enter with Mr. Valenzuela; that he met Mr. Valenzuela at a house in Escondido, which is some 50 miles north of the border.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How could he -- did he justify how long he had been in the country?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.

The witness, Mr. Valenzuela, the indication was from his statement who had been in the country six years, the witness had been in the country between a day and a half and possibly as little as 12 hours when he arrived at the house in Escondido.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What did he testified to as to communicating that information to this respondent?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He denied any communication whatsoever, one way or the other.

And the point, of course, is that although he was the one witness that the Government chose to charge the other witnesses were apparently in his company, and it is conceivable that these witnesses would have said something to Mr. Valenzuela such as for instance, one saying to the other in his presence, “Do you remember when we were up in the Imperial Valley three years ago picking those grapes?”

Which would indicate to Valenzuela that albeit without illegal status, they had not in fact illegally entered the country within the last three years because as this Court recognizes, I think, in Brignoni-Ponce.
The Hispanic population of Southern California is large and in fact there are large numbers of people illegally there who have been there for many, many years.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What the -- what was the defendant charged with, transporting whom?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He was charged with transporting Romero-Morales, the one witness who remained.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so, whether he knew anything about Morales, Morales was available to testify?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That was my point, Justice White.
The point is that these witnesses apparently got in the car with Romero as a group.
And so, the relevant issue is not in fact what the case is but what Valenzuela's state of mind is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let's -- let's suppose that defendant knew what -- about this particular witness.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That he was not only an alien but that he hadn't -- that he had just been in the country for two days.
There's no maps at the end of the case, I take it.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No matter what the other witnesses might have said about them.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: About their own particular status, that's correct.

But the issue is the -- the factual setting is such that anything -- any one of the witnesses could have said to the other.Valenzuela could have perceived that they were there together, that they were friends, that they were in the same status and what was true as to one was true as to the other.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the -- the witness who was there said he didn't say anything to the defendant?
Is that right?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Correct.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As to how long he had been there or --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.
And as to that particular element of the offense, the Government's proof was deficient.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Did he -- did he saying anything --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He denies --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: -- that he quotes either the two who had been deported?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, sir.
He did not.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Was he asked any questions about that?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I'm not sure.
I think the question that was put to him was, “Did you have any conversation with him?”
And the answer was no.
But, of course, in order to crosscheck to see if that was a correct statement --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Was there any question -- well, did you -- did the driver have any conversation with the two deported aliens?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I'm not sure if that question was put or not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how about on cross-examination of that witness?
Or he testified for the defendant?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: We called him as a witness at the motion to dismiss.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if you don't want him to see -- if you would have asked him that the other witnesses or the other aliens or whoever they were -- however you might want to call them, did the other aliens have any conversations with the driver?
That he said -- that he said yes, you would -- you might have --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, what was that conversation?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then you could have said, “Well, what was the conversation?”

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, but the -- the point is that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you didn't -- you didn't even take this opportunity to demonstrate that there might have been some help from the testimony of these other witnesses?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because if he would have said, “No, they didn't say a word to the driver,” you might -- there isn't much use those witnesses would have been to --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, they could have -- they could have been of help in another way.

For instance, if in fact these witnesses -- Romero-Morales was not necessarily telling the truth, one or more of those witnesses could have been in the United States, could have been involved in smuggling Romero or could have in fact been legally within the United States.
We don't know absent talking to those witnesses.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know, but the question is about Romero, and not them.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: It's the question is whether those witnesses could help with respect to the charge --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, I gather what you said earlier, Mr. Iredale, was that one of them might have said in the hearing in presence of the driver and this (Inaudible), might have said -- up in the great country three years ago and even though he denied that they had said anything, they might have come and testified that they did indeed say something.
And that's what was said, and your point is that this would have a bearing on the knowledge of the defendant.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they would have had to be saying something about Romero, not about them.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Or something that the defendant could have inferred related to Romero --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's what I was saying.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: -- or to the group of them because --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If he had said -- he had said any of those things to the respondent in this case, the respondent could have told his lawyer and his lawyer could have made a proffer that this witness would say -- that I talked about up in the great country.
And that's not here.
So what inference do you draw from that?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Given the rule of law, as it exists and the fact that any such requirement may well trench on the defendant's Fifth Amendment right to remain silent, I would submit that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This is not the defendant testifying.
This is the lawyer testifying.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: A proffer through counsel when such a proffer was made.
The proffer was made that these witnesses --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The proffer was made about picking the grapes?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, no.
The proffer --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm talking about something specific that you're not talking about.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No.
The issue was raised --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If -- if these witnesses had said anything in that car that would have helped him, he could have told the lawyer and the lawyer could have made a proffer.
That's it, isn't it?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, assuming that Valenzuela remembered accurately what happened, and assuming that he trusted his lawyer --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I would assume that if a man's on the trial for his liberty, remembers, and if he doesn't remember, God help him.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: And if the witnesses aren't there to help him, God help him.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, but I mean, what are these witnesses going to testify to?
As of right now, what are they going to -- tell me, what are they going to testify to?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That's the problem.
I can't tell you, Justice Marshall, what they would have testified to because they weren't there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What did your client tell you?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I wasn't the lawyer in the court below.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what did the client tell his lawyer?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I don't know, Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So how can we do any business?
Nobody knows anything around that.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Because the witnesses aren't there.
All the Government would have had to have done would have been to hold them for a reasonable period of time.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: All you did was write to these two Mexicans letters in English.
How do you know if they can read it?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: They were translated in Spanish, Justice Marshall, and the Spanish was sent to them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Spanish?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.
And both letters came back, marked “No está aquí,” This person is not here.
We couldn't subpoena the witnesses.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you think that discharged all your responsibility?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I must confess that I still find some difficulty in understanding what their testimony could have done to help the particular case even if they had said they had been in the great vineyards four years ago.
There's no presumption they've been in the United States continuously since then.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And they took off, there was flight here.
The route was such that it tended to corroborate the Government's case.
There are a lot of physical facts.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I agree, but the issue is not what in the light most favorable to the Government, the evidence would --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I think that in the light most favorable to the defendant, I don't really know what these other passengers could have done.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well it --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It would have belied the testimony of the one man who was admittedly just had entered the day before.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, what Valenzuela could have argued through his counsel to a jury is, sure, he knew they were illegally here, he knew he was illegally here, but there was no basis for him knowing.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That he's been hiding in this place for four years, is that the idea?
I mean if the whole circumstances certainly are not consistent with over three years before they suddenly chased him via the checkpoint.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Well, many of the people who are illegally in California go from Southern California where they work up to the North and they have to get through the checkpoint.
And then, they come back down South and work in the South and then they go back up North without necessarily entering back into Mexico.

And he could have inferred that or believed that that was the situation here; even though admittedly, he knew they were without status, he could have inferred they were coming not from Mexico but from the Imperial Valley up to the Central Valley to pick crops there.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Iredale, suppose the respondents here had been driving on the van with 30 aliens and 29 of them are released and there is evidence to support a conclusion -- a reasonable conclusion by a jury that one of them was knowingly transported.
Does it make any difference that 29 of them have disappeared?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I would say it would depend on the facts of the particular case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, let me read you his testimony when they asked him why he fled at the checkpoint.
“Why didn't you stop?”
His answer was, “Well, I did stop but since I was bringing in the people, I already knew that I had -- it was too late, it was done.”
What do you make of that testimony?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That he -- it could be argued first of all that he had some knowledge of their illegal status in the United States.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You say it could be argued.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: But was argued --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: -- by the Government.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And could a reasonable jury conclude --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That they were illegal -- that he knew they were illegally in the United States?
Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But that doesn't -- that would not --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: But that didn't go to the three-year element.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, even if -- if you lose this case, I take it the conviction still would have to be reviewed in the Ninth Circuit.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There was no trial.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, he was convicted in the court below.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, exactly.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He was convicted in the court below, the Ninth Circuit reversed the conviction in this Court --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What do you mean?
But they reversed the conviction on the ground that -- that you want to argue.
