turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if we set that aside, I take it your appeal would be reinstated in the -- in the Court of Appeals.
They would still have to review the evidence.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: There was no issue raised as to that.
The only issue --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) But you're telling us it was the Government's proof that's absolutely deficient on -- on the knowledge with respect to the three years.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That was not argued in the Court of Appeals.
We relied on Mendez-Rodriguez solely.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, which again -- let me come back to what do you -- what's your version of what he meant when he said, “I already knew that I had had it”?
What do you think he meant?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: He knew he was going to be arrested.
He knew there were people illegally in the country who were in his car.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In his car.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: But, he supposed --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Doesn't that go to his knowledge that this were at least --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- at least one illegal alien?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: But the statute has two mandatory of requirements.
One is that he knows they are illegaly here.
The second is that he knows they entered within three years, and I think that statement goes to the first.
The Government can argue it goes to the second, but that's the issue in dispute in the case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But then, as Justice White has asked you, why isn't that open for a review when the Ninth Circuit never reached that issue, it never considered it?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: It -- it was never raised because we felt the Mendez-Rodriguez issue was absolutely all in our favor and we wanted to raise that issue only.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think you're foreclosed on a remand if you lose this case?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: I would hope not.

I would hope we would not lose the case given the fact that we feel that the procedure here followed by the Government was completely unreasonable, especially in light of the practices in the Southern District of California.
This would testify two in the record.
Now, I'd like to explain it because I have a very reasonable effort to balance all of the interests of all of the parties.
When the defendant is arrested and charged with an offense involving felony illegal alien smuggling, he's bought in to Court, almost always within 24 hours of the arrest.
At the rule five arraignment counsel is appointed for him, counsel is also at that time appointed for the witnesses.
A date is set for preliminary examination which is nearly always within 10 days of the date of the initial appearance in Court.
And Mr. Justice Stevens, there's nothing magical about the 10-day figure and it's not common law.
The reason why it's 10 days is because the Government wants 10 days to be able to indict the case.
Defense Counsel Franklin could conduct his investigation in much less time.

It is the practice in the Southern District of California that the Government provides discovery, the reports to defense counsel on an informal basis and the witnesses are all interviewed before that initial appearance.

And at that appearance, after the interview of the witnesses has taken place, counsel appears with the defendant, the Government is required at that time to make a showing as to which witnesses they want.
Defense counsel is required to make a showing as to which if any witnesses he wants.
In one magistrate's code, it must be done by an affidavit under oath --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what kind of a showing must he make?
What if he says, for example, all of these people were in the vehicle and I'd like to hold them all because they might conceivably benefit the defense?
Is that enough?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That's -- that's insufficient.
You see, the standard of conceivable benefit does not apply at these hearings because --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what is the standard of that hearing then?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: The standard -- the defendant must be able to show that the witness could offer relevant, material and exculpatory evidence that would not otherwise be obtainable from the witnesses that the Government is keeping.
In other words, counsel is held at that hearing to a very specific standard.
The reason is he has been able to interview these witnesses.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And does he say at that hearing what the exculpatory evidence would be?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
He's required to because absence such a showing, the magistrate will order the discharge of the witness immediately.
And as a matter of fact, at this hearing probably 50% to 60% of the witnesses are discharged.In every case, the Government keeps material witnesses in custody.
Even if this Court were to adhere to the Government's position, the number of material witnesses to retain in the Southern District of California would not decrease.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if the -- what if the defendant objects to an action of the magistrate in discharging a particular witness or group of witnesses, I take it he can preserve that point and object at trial and conceivably either have the indictment thrown out or the Court of Appeals reverses it.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Justice Rehnquist, that's correct.
In other words, a verbatim record is kept of the magistrate's proceedings.
And defense makes his proffer, the Government may oppose it, the magistrates rule, and then it would be presented to the District Court for his resolution of the issue.
But the point is at this material witness hearing, the defense can properly be held to that high standard that they are held to.
We're not allowed to come in and say, “Oh, well, maybe he could help.
We don't know exactly.”
Because we've had the chance to interview, the defense is required at that hearing to show specifically.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But there's nothing final about the magistrate's decision either, I take it, the defendant there can pursue the question into the District Court or the Court of Appeals, if he wanted.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That's absolutely correct, but the witnesses ordered release at that time, if the magistrates still hold --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can I -- Can I ask you?
Suppose a day after arrest, the witnesses are all available and the defense counsel interviews them, he's been appointed and he interviews them.
And then the 10 days go by and at the hearing, it turns out that the Government, two days after the arrest had deported all but -- all but the witnesses they wanted to retain.
And then, the defense counsel says, “Well, I want those witnesses that were deported.”
What would the judge say to him then?
Wouldn't he make you show --

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: That's exactly right, and that would properly be held.

In other words, Mr. Justice White, if I understand correctly, what you're saying is, given the interview, then the defense would have to make a specific particularized definite concrete exculpatory showing.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So if the Government -- if the Government made the witnesses available to a defense counsel even for a day and if he actually interviewed them, the Government -- if it was confident enough -- could just deport them if he -- if he -- they were sure you couldn't make the showing.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Let me just say I hesitated the formulation of a day because depending on the facts of the case, a reasonable time might be necessary.
You might need to see, for instance, in order to interview intelligently, you need to know what the Government is going to charge.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right.
I'll -- I'll just say it -- I'll say, okay, a reasonable time.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: A reasonable time, given the reasonable time and adequate opportunity to know what the Government is going to charge.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Actually, my example was that you actually had interviewed.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If you had actually interviewed and then the Government took the risk of deporting them, you would have to then make the showing that you -- district showing at the hearing.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Assuming a reasonable opportunity for investigation --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I said actually you do.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Absolutely.
That would -- then it would be appropriate, because then you would be in a position to say --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right, you hadn't interviewed but you had had a reasonable time to interview.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose you hadn't interviewed but you had had a reasonable time to do so and had neglected it.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Then it's waiver.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You suggested that there's no reason why the Government should keep all these witnesses in the country.
Now, it's not unusual that there would be 29 or 30 in one batch.
We've seen such cases.
Now, I'll go back to my hypothetical.
Thirty of them stashed around a van, concealed and -- are you suggesting that all 30 of these people have got to be retained in the country to prove that the driver knowingly brought them over?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Either -- for a brief period of time, yes.For a reasonable period of time, three, four, five days.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: All 30 of them?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes.
For a reasonable period of time and only to allow an interview.
It could be a summary.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then what you're suggesting is it isn't enough if the Government sustains the burden of proof and assumes -- it sustains the reasonable burden of proof that one of them was there illegally.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: In Washington versus Texas, this Court hold -- held that the Government violates compulsory process when it makes unavailable to the defense or prevents from testifying a witness who is an eye witness to an event and who is physically and mentally able to testify about events which he personally witnessed which are relevant to the defense.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the only issue is the -- the -- the knowing aspect, isn't it?
So, there's nothing to witness in the traditional sense of seeing, is there?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Mr. Justice Burger, this case isn't a typical case.
The Government chose this case as its so called “test case” so they chose the facts they felt would be most favorable to them.
In most of these cases, the issue is not knowledge but in many cases, alibi, mistaken identity, and in fact, who is doing what with whom and to whom.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It would have been a better case if Morales or whatever his name was when he was put on the stand had said, “Yes, I told the defendant that I had been -- that I was an illegal alien and that I had been here for only two days.”

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: From the Government's point of view, it would have been a very good case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But suppose he had to testify that way, would you be here then?

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: Yes, because those other witnesses could have testified that Morales --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That Morales really didn't know what he was talking about.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: No, that he was lying.
That Morales was the man who was -- who was the smuggler, which is what happens sometimes in these cases.
It's hard to tell the smuggler sometimes from the witnesses, which is why counsel is appointed for them.
The point, I think, is that the Government cannot accurately or fairly determine --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because he might -- he might be lying because he's getting a break from the Government.

turn.speaker: eugene_g_iredale
turn.label: Mr. Eugene G. Iredale
turn.text: All of these witnesses are subject to prosecution, and all of them are interviewed initially by the Border Patrol.
I thank the Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have anything further, Mr. Phillips?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Just a few remarks, Mr. Chief Justice.
Initially, I've point out from the record that Romero-Morales was asked whether he had heard any testimony or any statements made to the driver by any of the illegal aliens who had been deported.
That's on page 44, the joint appendix as to --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: How did he answer?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, both in terms of the car and then at the house prior to --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you didn't hear him.
Did that mean that there weren't any?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Did -- he just said he didn't hear any statements made, but he was in their presence and if you're inside a car and they were together in the same room of the house --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You said that was page 44?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, at the bottom.
With regard to the reasonableness of the practice in the Southern District to California, it sounds good when you talk about individualized cases and the step-by-step determination.
But it seems to me that the aggregate effect of the rule in the Southern District of California is best demonstrated by the statistics.
Five thousand illegal aliens held in custody in order for 36 trials, and we don't even know of those 36 trials, how many if any illegal aliens ever testified on behalf of a defendant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On that point, Mr. Phillips, that -- that page 30 of the read brief, they give some figures about the number of cases and they say there were only 11 Mendez-Rodriguez motions filed in a total of 239 cases and only one motion was granted.
Is that -- is that accurate?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: We -- we did not independently evaluate that; although, we wouldn't be terribly surprised if there aren't a lot of Mendez-Rodriguez cases in light of the fact that the Government's practice is typically to detain all illegal aliens and/or to dismiss the charges.
So you wouldn't expect there'd be very many cases.
It doesn't come up because we assume --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'm assuming this case is an atypical case then.
The Government deviated from its normal practice.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: In this case, the Government tested the theory of how much prejudice has to be demonstrated.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: With regard to a couple of points made --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: May I ask one other question?
The 5000 that have been detained, for how long?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, it varies from one day to 120 days, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But do we don't -- we don't have any notion of what the average period is?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the average according to the marshall is something in excess of five days per person.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I -- I believe counsel that counsel for the respondent indicated that even if the Government won this decision, it wouldn't alter the number of witnesses retained.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, I don't know where -- I don't understand how the respondent can make that claim.

It seems to me inconceivable in light of cases like (Inaudible) where the Government has to detain 39 material witnesses for an excess of two weeks because of a decision and expressly on those facts by the Ninth Circuit.
How could it be that if the Government altered its position, a number of illegal aliens wouldn't be reduced?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: How about the suggestion that the witnesses be retained for simply long enough to let defense counsel interview them and then let the Government deport at its peril?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I mean, that sounds good in theory, Your Honor, but the reality is that we simply can't get defense counsel there and ready to go contrary to what respondents suggest.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, but if an opportunity were provided and they didn't take advantage of it, I suppose that's too bad.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That may, well -- yes, Your Honor.
I think that's probably true although we don't -- I mean, you have to set specific deadlines and the Ninth Circuit at this point has been disinclined to say anything less than 10 days.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: All right, but let's suppose there are.

I mean what's the matter with that then, with the shorter time and then yat point, Mr. Phillips, that -- that page 30 of the read brief, they give some figures about the number of cases and they say there were only 11 Mendez-Rodriguez motions filed in a total oou could deport at your peril, I suppose?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, if -- if we thought it would work and then we could in fact deport at our peril and given them two days, I just think we're going to have trouble if that -- having that enforced in the Ninth Circuit.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you're certainly acting at your peril now.
You don't say that you can just -- well, I guess you do.

Your submission really is that if you -- once you interview them and that Government makes a decision that they would have no exculpatory evidence that you can deport them and -- and as long as you act in good faith, that's the end of the matter, no matter what the showing is on the other side.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Ultimately that's --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's your first submission.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I mean, we then have to make that kind of a determination with regard to each of the one million illegal aliens who are captured.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Have you ever had the Court agree with you on that, that first position?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Who?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The Ninth Circuit holds that if we make a determination, that there is no connection in -- in time or space between the illegal alien and a criminal defendant, then we can --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No one has ever -- you say on the facts of this case, if you make a good faith judgment that even though they were present on the spot, that they would have no evidence, that's the end of the matter no matter what kind of a showing the other side is.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Sure, what we're suggesting though is that there is not a demonstrable difference -- yes, that is our submission but that's not demonstrably different from the judgment --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Suppose we rejected that, what's your next fallback?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Is that -- is that respondent under any circumstances must demonstrate with some concreteness the materiality of the witnesses that were lost which they cannot do in this case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And -- and is -- is that rule extended in any circuit that you know of?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I believe the Fifth Circuit adapts a rule very much like that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think that's the rule the Fifth Circuit adapts?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I think so, Your Honor, because in the Avila-Dominguez case, those -- those witnesses were witnesses to the crime at the time they were arrested and the Court held that they could be -- that they could be sent away.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So you -- so, if you would be acting at your peril in deporting witnesses under the Fifth Circuit rule?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Certainly, to the extent there is a review, but -- I mean we don't -- we don't, you know wither from the notion that there'll be judicial review of our determination.
I think we'll be right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you regularly take that risk in the Fifth Circuit now, or do you hold everybody?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, we regularly take that risk, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In the -- under the Fifth Circuit rule?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, once we make an evaluation and if we think there is no material exculpatory evidence, we will deport.
The -- we won't keep more than several.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because the rule is not that different from the Ninth Circuit rule, you don't think it's so strict that you can't take that risk.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I mean, it's not my decision to take that risk but the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it's somebody's decision.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's true, the Border Patrol agents and the Fifth Circuit have on occasion released illegal aliens especially in circumstances such like the (Inaudible) position -- situation where you have a large number of illegal aliens all of whom seem to say the same thing.
We don't detain all 39 of them in the Fifth Circuit, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: My question -- my question really is that if you are -- if you don't -- if we do not agree with your first submission, would the Government regularly -- and I suppose you had to operate under the Fifth Circuit rule -- would the Government regularly release a lot of witnesses that it would not release under the Ninth Circuit rule?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well then, there would certainly be some instances where there is clear inculpatory statements made by the -- by the defendant at the time of his arrest and where all other statements that are sworn by the illegal aliens are cumulative, we will almost assuredly release some illegal aliens.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
We'll hear arguments next in --
